author: Babelight
body:
I’m going to share something I saw on Yahoo finance. Btw, I hold over 4000 shares so I’m long. But it’s also become a meme stock on wallstreetbets.

“Here's the deal. PLTR is a solid, growth company helmed by Peter Thiel (co-founder of PayPal) and also other billionaires. The company is not hurting for cash, but is still in its early years even though it was founded 15+ years ago. There is tremendous upside in government contracts, and other sectors.

IMO, this stock will be $100+ in a couple of years, but it won't happen overnight. Still a 500% gain in 2-3 years beats the avg 8-10% annual gain of index funds or 2% for savings accounts.

This is a simple correction due to the recent run from $12 to $30 in a matter of weeks.

Nothing fundamentally changed with this business. 

However, 

1) you should ONLY invest money in the stock market that you won't need for any reason for the next 5+ years

2) you should always expect 10-20% pullback in a new position and should have additional funds at your disposal to buy on dips to average down

3) ONLY invest in stocks on which you did your own research and you fundamentally believe in the company's LONG TERM trajectory. This will help you weather short term pull backs and correction and you won't panic sell at the worst time”

author: DoubleKillGG
body:
Bear case: 

* For it being hyped up, I'm hardly seeing any support from Europeans where they have their operations. 
* People who bought in after hours on the CNBC pump are going to wake up to a rude awakening on Monday open. 
* Anything Paysafe does / can do, their competition already does / can do better. 

Bull case:

* People claim it's the Paypal for Europeans and can be used on gambling sites and video games.
* Hard to fight the hype until it's run up excessively too much and attracts aggressive short sellers.

Rule of thumb: If you're unsure, it's probably better to sit on the sidelines and look for another SPAC.

author: ValueInvestingIsDead
body:
Anyone in tech circle knows they're betting on the likelihood of Tesla dominating the energy / battery future, and not the cars themselves.

Tech investors bet on end-game profits today. This is nothing new. It's why we've had the same conversations with every TANG/FANG/FAGMAN stonk out there. It's not the product (autos), it's the platform (energy).

If you're looking at the last quarterly report and throwing a standard multiplier on a single metric, you're gonna be a shit tech investor for life. 

It's goddamn tech 101 and Peter Thiel (Paypal Mafia) outlines this so clearly in his book Zero to One.

author: trillionmarketcap
body:
According to the wiki article, it swelled up overnight. He went to undergo a two week treatment but they couldn't find a solution so they continued to grow.
Two years later he underwent an eight week treatment and it still didn't resolve it. At this point they had grown to the point where he was nearly immobile.

The surgery required to correct it costs seven figures and he only got $2000 in paypal donations and had to suffer in pain with the dehabilitating condition until the medical center agreed to perform the surgery for free.

Years later he died in 2014.

What's sad is OP using a documentary footage of a deceased man who suffered years in excruciating and dehabiliating pain in a tasteless shitpost meme to gain internet points. What's even sadder are the upvotes.

author: Turbulent_Bit8683
body:
Thank you for doing this very useful. However, some add on information EV is not market cap that’s why the debt is not showing up in mostly income statement based assessment - also this does not show global coverage of PayPal vs Paysafe eg Xoom is big money earner for PayPal and as is their deal with Synchrony for deferred payment etc. these are all critical for valuation purposes and the most important is that Paysafe is not in the most mature market ie US barriers to entry include competition PayPal, Square Affirm and coming up SOFi the markets will get saturated here leaving very little for Paysafe similarly in India and China there are large payment processing companies.

I may be biased but I don’t see Paysafe becoming relevant outside of UK and the challenge is PayPal or Square or others can enter UK a lot more easily meaning Paysafe’s ability to counter will be limited and growth challenges will drive this business into oblivion! Drastic but just to drive the point that these guys will keep showing good margins while eroding market share and become irrelevant in 5 years!

Again guys I am making a bear case for these guys feel free to challenge my assertions.

author: matthewleehess
body:
> It isn't sustainable though.

Despite your statement, it has already been sustaining for decades.  Buying and selling pre-owned games is not a new venture for them.
  
>  1  People can (and do) just sell their shit on ebay/craigslist for more, and if you're buying there, you're paying way less.

People have been doing that for decades, too.

Don't know about you, but it's not worth my time to bother with taking photos, creating a listing, waiting for the auction to sell, waiting for buyer to pay, finding a box, packing the box, figuring out shipping costs, printing a shipping label, driving to the post office to get it shipped, and then hoping the seller doesn't make a claim with PayPal or eBay and get their money back for no reason, just to score an extra $5.

I'm just going to take this game that I finished to GameStop, and maybe get $10 credit towards the next thing I'm going to grab.  It's instant, and zero extra effort.  

> 2  Digital games are kind of hard to sell at the counter in GameStop.

Yet, GameStop is still making money off of Xbox digital game sales.  Without the overhead of retail locations, employees, and other brick and mortar costs.  One of their highest profit percentage categories actually, and something that they are trying to aggressively expand for FY21.

author: jbourbon69
body:
Listen, you have no debt and enough savings to survive if your job disappears (which sounds very unlikely) and you have money doing nothing in savings assuming you have funds being pumped into 401k aND HSA Account also from your paychecks. Since you’re young and time in the market is most important I recommend you play a long term game. Dont worry about price of a stock if you think they still have room to grow so identify a list of your top 5 stock picks (hopefully some are in different sectors) and keep pumping money into them every 2 weeks just like your 401k is being pumped by your paychecks. If a stock you chose dumps significantly go double down on it to drop your average (Lookup dollar cost averaging or DCA). Now that you understand this strategy what stocks?

Well you seem to work for a cyber company so lets invest in some cyber companies since you know how they operate and with latest cyber attacks which will continue. 

My cyber pick is $NET, sitting at $25B I think in 5 years we can see $125b to $150b. 

Online gambling with sports due to new covid restrictions will make DKNG and Penn huge

Now covid opened a gateway to health and bio research boost. 
My online health growth stock is $TDOC which my company uses and is cheaper and efficient for all your medical needs and as a virtual health tech platform and especially as companies shift to using it. Easily a $250 stock in 5 years. 

Technology is huge with software and data, with AI being a growth engine. 
My stock picks are more than just 1 since prices of some are either too overpriced or revenue isn’t there yet; SNOW, AI, PLTR, WDAY

Social media stock choices and streaming since we all know these platforms are great for company growth and marketing; SNAP, ROKU, and PINS. Disney is cheap to because they will find a way out of their amusement park hole from covid. 

Currency related platforms through which money securely transfers from one user to the next; $SQ (owns cash app) and also invest in Bitcoin when it dips, throw in paypal if you think they have room still. 


Then of course meme stocks throw in a few stacks at EV stocks (TSLA, nio, etc) and bio stocks. 

Safe plays could be banks since they are cheap but your risk is low since you are young so dont throw much at safe plays but hold some to balance portfolio

I know i threw a whole bunch of stocks but choose whichever sectors you understand and use and are bullish on for long term. The goal is to hold and buy more and double down if there ever is a significant dip (10%+)

author: KapGains
body:
Evening all, hoping for some two cents on LT investment approach….

**Background**: Long time ‘casual’ dabbler in cannabis stocks last few years (never got too burned fortunately). Starting to frame a more structured portfolio given amount of capital at play starting a couple months ago (\~$200k CAD).

**Time Horizon/Goal**: Looking for long term growth over next 4-5 years from a balanced North American cannabis portfolio (banking on full or pseudo-US legalization, material absorption of market share from of illicit markets, significant consumer habit changes, resolution of key supply chain challenges e.g. dispensary rollouts, price appreciation from brand development, ect). You know all this better then me...

**TLDR:** 

1) What’s a good (non-active) “set it and forget it” 5-year investment allocation. (% I am leaning below)?

2) Should I allocate across all these names I’ve scratched the surface on (diversify on industry) or select a handful that I feel more comfortable with over the rest? {forgive the rudimentary categorizations}

**· (25%) Core LP’s (4-5 names or HMMJ)**   *APHA, ACB, Weed, CWEB, CRON, HEXO, OGI, VFF*

**· (60%) Core MSO’s (5-6 names or HMUS)** *FFNT, AYR, CCHW, CL, CURA, GTII, HARV, JUSH, TER, TRUL, (TBD Verano Holdings)*

**· (15%) Flyer Picks (5-15 smaller cap or distressed)**   *TGIF, XLY, CXXI, RIV, FAF, GLH, IAN, ICAN, INDS, MMEN, NEPT, PLTH, RTI, RWB, SOL, FIRE, TBP, VREO, WMD*

author: jakekap5
body: By the time these MSO’s can uplist, they will already have created significant economies of scale and moats within the states they operate in. If the big pharma and CPG companies want to get in, they will have to pay hefty premium for any of the top MSO’s. The cultivation and dispensing licenses in limited license states will inevitably prove to be extremely valuable assets, based on the FCF’s that they will generate once regulations ease. None of the LPs have any of these assets, perhaps with the exception of Canopy through Acreage and TER

body: So now we have CURA, TRUL, TER, AYR & JUSH as the MSOs who have reached a NATH in 2020. Interesting. PLTH & GRWG as well.

author: MeesterWeen
body: TER has run hard but I think still has room. ASML too. I’m a big fan of the testing and equipment makers
